title: SB 1.17.19 Part 4 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse |  | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 28-02-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiraandhasya Gyananjani Chalakaya Chaksharunmeeritam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, offering obeisances to the spiritual master and the Lord.

segments.key_quote: They imagine some form inside and they simply want to concentrate completely on that form and when they are able to absorb their mind completely in meditation on that imagined form they think they have reached the perfection of self-realization.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the topic of Patanjali Rishi and his Yoga Sutra, explaining the Ashtanga Yoga system and its focus on meditation on an imagined form for self-realization.

segments.key_quote: he is presenting the the truth the absolute truth as the supreme personality of godhead krishna as the ultimate goal of all processes of uh knowledge
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts Patanjali's philosophy with Vedanta, emphasizing that the ultimate goal of knowledge is to know Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, who is the source of Vedic knowledge.

segments.key_quote: patanjali rishi he is talking about a process of uh meditation so first yama niyama asana pranayama pratyahara dharana dhyana samadhi
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the eight steps of Ashtanga Yoga according to Patanjali, including Yama, Niyama, and the process of meditation, highlighting the restrictions and the need for sense control.

segments.key_quote: what is a that ultimate reality from whom everything is emanating who is the ultimate goal of all processes of knowledge whose ultimate reality eternally existing that they have no idea
segments.summary: The speaker criticizes the followers of Patanjali for not knowing the ultimate reality and for imagining it as something impersonal (Nirvishesha) or void (Shunyavada).

segments.key_quote: they say this world is unreal it's illusion grand illusion it doesn't exist we just imagine that it exists it really exists
segments.summary: The speaker refutes the idea that the world is an illusion, explaining that it is the interaction of the Lord's energy, guided by His will.

segments.key_quote: This is the perfect explanation given in the Bhagavad Gita and the Vedanta philosophy. Perfect explanation.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the composition of material nature according to the Bhagavad Gita, including the eight elements and the three modes of material nature.

segments.key_quote: But Patanjali doesn't describe clearly this object of meditation as the Supreme Personality of Godhead Krishna, as Vishnu, who is the eternal, transcendental person, that he does not describe.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts Patanjali's system with the Vedic understanding of meditating on Vishnu as Paramatma within the heart, emphasizing that Patanjali's system lacks a clear understanding of the Supreme Personality of Godhead.

segments.key_quote: So, this imaginary form is based on the wrong understanding that this material world itself is illusion, is false.
segments.summary: The speaker connects Patanjali's concept of an imaginary form with the Mayavadi philosophy, which considers the material world to be an illusion, and clarifies that reality lies behind the constant changes.

segments.key_quote: While we are in the grip of illusion, while we have this material body, while we are in ignorance, unless we take help of a self-realized bona fide spiritual master coming in parampara who is himself situated in transcendence and who can properly explain everything
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing the difficulty of attaining truth without the guidance of a self-realized spiritual master in parampara, highlighting the limitations of speculation and logic.
